Award.AwardTitle: Thermodynamics and Structure of Chemically Heterogeneous Solid-Liquid Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Brian B. Laird of the University of Kansas is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division for the theoretical and computational study of solid-liquid interface. Such interfaces are common in nature and technology, from the commonly observed interface between ice and water to the surfaces of nanoparticles in solution. Understanding the structure and thermodynamics of such interfaces is important in a broad array of fields including chemistry, materials science, nano-engineering, metallurgy, colloidal science and biophysics. For example, the energy cost in forming a particular solid-liquid interface control whether the liquid completely covers (or wets) the solid surface or instead, beads up into droplets, like water on a freshly waxed car. Direct experimental study of solid-liquid interfaces, however, is difficult - especially for metallic systems where high temperatures and lack of transparency to spectroscopic probes severely limit experimental study. As a result, computational methods have been crucial in developing a detailed atomic-level picture of the interfacial region. In this work, molecular simulation techniques are used to examine, at an atomic level, the properties of so-called chemically heterogeneous solid-liquid interfaces; namely, interfaces in which the solid and liquid phases are significantly different in chemical composition. The particular systems used in this study were chosen specifically to address fundamental questions in interface science, while at the same time be relevant to specific technological applications, such as understanding the stability of nanoparticles in solution, mechanisms for metal embrittlement and the growth of sapphire nanowires. The project also contributes to the training of students and postdocs in the techniques of computational chemistry, liquid-state physics and materials science and affords them a considerable experience in advanced scientific programming. These skills have wide use in a vast array of applications in chemistry, engineering, materials science, pharmaceutical science, biology and physics and gives them considerable marketability in any aspect of computational science and technology.


The overall goal of this proposed research is to understand, on a fundamental molecular level, how the thermodynamic and structural properties of chemically heterogeneous solid-liquid interfaces are shaped by atomic and molecular interactions and interfacial geometry. This effort requires both (a) the development, evaluation and application of new computational methods and force fields to study the interfaces between condensed phases and (b) the extension of existing methods to classes of systems beyond those for which the methods were developed. In this project, a concerted program of method development, molecular-dynamics simulations and applied statistical mechanics is developed to perform a systematic study of the thermodynamics and structure of chemically heterogeneous solid-liquid interfaces. The project focuses specifically on three classes of systems: (a) Chemically heterogeneous metal/metal solid-liquid interfaces, in particular a study of the interface between aluminum and liquid gallium, which is of interest as a model system for the study of liquid-metal embrittlement. (b) Metal/metal-oxide solid-liquid interfaces using the alumina(s)/Al(l) interface as a test-bed - a system which provides a rare opportunity to directly compare experiment and simulation results for a solid-liquid interface at the atomic level. (c) Fluids at curved surfaces. The curvature dependence of the interfacial free energy for a number of systems is investigated including fluids at corrugated surfaces, convex colloidal particles and convex surfaces. Results are examined to assess the validity of Morphometric Thermodynamics, a recently developed theory of curved surface thermodynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solid-liquid interfaces (SLIs) are common in nature and technolgy, from the commonly observed interface between ice and water to the surface of nanoparticles in solution. Understanding the structure and thermodynamics of such interfaces is important in a broad array of fields, including chemistry, materials science, nanoengineering, metallurgy, colloidal science and biophysics. For example, the energy cost in forming a particular solid-liquid interface will control whether the liquid will completely cover (or \wet") the solid surface or will, instead, bead up into droplets, like water on a freshly waxed car. Direct experimental study of SLIs  is difficult - especally for metallic systems where high temperatures and opacity to spectroscopic probes limits experimental study. Thus, computational methods have been crucial in developing a detailed atomic-level picture of the interfacial region. In this work, molecular simulation techniques were used to examine, at an atomic level the properties of so-called chemically heterogeneous SLIs; namely, interfaces in which the two phases differ significantly in chemical composition. The particular systems studied were chosen specically to address fundamental questions in interface science and  be relevant to specific technological applications, such as, the stability of nanoparticles in solution, metal embrittlement and the growth of sapphire nanowires. The project also contributed to the training of students and postdocs in the techniques of computational chemistry/materials science, liquid-state physics  and will give them experience in advanced scientic programming. These skills have wide use in a vast array of applications in chemistry, engineering, materials science, pharmacy, biology and physics and will give them considerable marketability in computational science and technology.

The overall goal of this proposed research was to understand, on a fundamental molecular level, how the thermodynamic and structural properties of chemically heterogeneous SLIs  are shaped by atomic and molecular interactions and interfacial geometry. This effort required both(a) the development, evaluation and application of new computational methods to study the interfaces between condensed phases and (b) the extension of existing methods to classes of systems beyond those for which the methods were developed. Using a concerted program of method development, molecular-dynamics simulations and applied statistical mechanics, we will perform a systematic study of the thermodynamics and structure of chemically heterogeneous solid-liquid interfaces. In this work, we will focus on three classes of systems:

(a) Fluids at curved surfaces: In this study we examined a model systems that have  been extremely important in the development of our understanding of fluids made up of hard-spheres and (in 2d) hard-disk particles. These systems are simple enough to be tractable, but still exhibit many of the generic properties of real fluids. We have calculated the surface thermodynamics (free energy, or ``surface tension") for these models at surfaces of varying curvature. Results were compared to existing theoretical results and have been able to resolve limitations of existing theories - namely, the so-called Morphometric Thermodynamics and classical density-functional theory. This work has led to four articles  during the grant period to the Journal of Chemical Physics and the Joural of Condensed Matter Physics, and one addition manuscript in preparation. 

(b) Chemically heterogeneous metal/metal SLIs: In this work we have studied three systems. In the first, we examined the interface between solid copper (Cu) and liquid lead (Pb). We have shown in a publication in the Journal of Chemical Physics, via simulation, that the structure of the copper surface has a profound effect on the ease with which supercooled liquid lead will solidify at the surface vis so-called `heterogeneous nucleation". When we replace the Cu with aluminium (Al) we show that the orientation of the Al surface has a significant effect on the spreading of liquid Pb droplets on the Al surface - an observation that has implications in industrial casting and braising - and in the experimentally-observed brownian motion of liquid Pb inclusions in solid Al. Three publications have resulted from this work.   In the final system in this section, we have examined the Al-Ga SLI. This is an important testbed system for the study of liquid-metal embrittlement - a potental failure mechanism for structural metals (search Youtube videos for "gallium" and "Coke can" for a number of facinating demonstrations of this phenomenon.) In a paper currently under peer review, we have characterized the structure and dynamics of this SLI.

(c)  Metal/metal-oxide solid-liquid interfaces:  Here we study the Al2O3(alumina)/Al(l) interface as a testbed - a system which provides a rare opportunity to directly compare experiment and simulation results for a solid-liquid interface at the atomic level. This study is considerably more difficult than the previous studies on SLIs because of the need to use so-called reactive potentials, which enable the breaking and forming of Al-O bonds in order to properly model the movement of oxygen in the system We have made much progress, but a final manuscript on this project is likely still a few months away.
